awd_titl_txt: Carbon Nanotube Textile Fabrication by Programmable Self-Assembly
awd_abstract_narration:
Carbon nanotubes are extremely fine, lightweight fibers having outstanding strength and electric properties.  With suitable weaving technology, smart carbon nanotube textiles could enable multi-functionalities such as sensing, thermal regulation, health monitoring, and wearable prosthetics with embedded energy storage. However, weaving carbon nanotubes into fabrics using current technologies faces several challenges due to their short lengths and their tendency to aggregate into random clusters.  This award studies programmable self-assembly of carbon nanotubes to overcome these challenges and fabricate smart textiles and fabrics. The fabrication process relies on liquid surface tension to autonomously weave carbon nanotubes into continuous fabrics. More broadly, the project advances the knowledge needed to transform nanostructure self-assembly processes to scalable nanomanufacturing technologies applicable to a wide range of industries and products, thus impacting national prosperity and society. The project engages middle and high school students, women and minorities in inspiring outreach programs at the intersection of engineering, biology and the arts. New education modules called The Art and Life of Cilia are developed to demonstrate a palette of nature-inspired fibrous materials and their use in designing various textures, patterns and functionalities. These education activities connect materials science and manufacturing to art and design using examples ranging from the physics of painting brushes and bird feathers to the processing of engineering materials. 

The objective of this study is to reveal the dynamics of capillary self-assembly of carbon nanotubes (CNTs) into meter-scale engineering textiles. Complex self-assembly dynamics, which occur at extremely small time and spatial scales, govern the uniformity of this fabrication process. By exploiting the dynamics of capillary self-assembly, a new paradigm of textile manufacturing by self-weaving can be realized. Programmable self-assembly can produce CNT textiles with unprecedented precision and repeatability at high throughput. This project includes a study of the kinetics of CNTs self-weaving by new mathematical dynamics models and experimental validation by in situ high-speed imaging. The processing conditions, including the choice of liquid, the residual polymers in the textile, and the weaving topology, are studied towards developing continuous roll-to-roll defect-free self-weaving process. A variety of complex self-woven textile architectures are produced by the programmable self-assembly of highly aligned CNTs, and studied for applications in smart textiles.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_div_long_name: Division of Civil, Mechanical, and Manufacturing Innovation

por.por_cntn:
This project aimed at studying a manufacturing method leveraging the assembly of elastic, thin, and long microstructures by self-directed capillary forces to produce useful materials and structures. One main application was the programmable self-weaving of textiles using carbon nanotubes. 

Towards this aim, the project included both experimental, theoretical, and numerical modeling efforts focusing on the effect of dynamics on elastocapillarity. In the past, research studies had demonstrated that the slow application and removal of liquids from thin elastic structures causes their deformation into predictable useful shapes, and hence is useful manufacturing process at the micro- and nanoscale. At these miniature scales, traditional large manipulation approaches face severe length and time scaling challenges. On the other hand, the capillary forces of small droplets can deform elastic structures, and have a parallel, self-directed nature which make them scalable. In this NSF project, we investigated the effect of fast application and removal of liquid droplets on the dynamic deformations of such elastic structures. 

We discovered several previously unknown physical phenomena which created unexpected opportunities and advancements in engineering applications. Firstly, we discovered and studied how the same group of thin fibers can self-assemble into various shapes based on the rate of liquid drainage, and we called this dynamic elastocapillarity to highlight the rate effect. We explained this effect theoretically and numerically.

Secondly, and unexpectedly, we realized that vertical microscale fins submerged within a liquid droplet deform in different directions based on the rate removal of this liquid droplet. This inspired a new research pursuit of engineering display devices, akin to e-paper, which have the great benefits of scalable pixel size, ultra-low energy consumption and stable, and persistent on-off states. This first-of-a kind concept gained significant media attention, since it was also based on a serendipitous discovery.

Thirdly, towards realizing the self-programmable assembly of textiles, we focused on developing numerical models to resolve this challenging technological problem, rather than performing trial-and-error experiments. We realized that the number of parameters to be adjusted to optimize this novel manufacturing process is not approachable by laborious trial-and-error. On the other hand, the modeling must use simplified approaches to handle the multi-physics, multi-time and length scales. Our numerical models showed promising results and were able to capture the complex behavior of dynamic elastocapillarity. Some of our mathematical models are still being prepared for future publication. In the future, these models can be leveraged to optimized the proposed manufacturing process of self-driven weaving.

Moreover, we trained graduate and undergraduate students on fabrication, small scale self-organization, and the use of self-driven physical phenomena like capillarity in manufacturing. We conducted outreach activities and created publicly accessible lectures on the topic on the internet. During the pandemic, we permormed "kitchen experiments" to show the effects of elastocapillarity on the behavior of pasta noodles, which was well-received by the media. The PI and researchers gave several invited articles in the USA and in Europe. 

 


Last Modified: 12/22/2023
Modified by: Sameh Tawfick

  • Capillary-induced polymorphic texture mimicking blooming flowers. Fluid flow from drainage holes at the base results in flower blooming and closing, respectively. The flower diameter is 5 mm.
    Jonghyun Ha, Yun Seong Kim and Sameh Tawfick
    Royalty-free (unrestricted use)
    Sameh Tawfick
    Blooming Flower Display
  • Physics, which is the online magazine of the American Physical Society, highlighted our research on the effect of dynamic capillarity on hair self-assembly.
    Website credit APS
    Copyrighted
    Sameh Tawfick
    Hair Self- Assembly Media Highlight
